The Articles of Confederation

America's First Constitution (1781-1789)

Explore History

America's First Constitution

The Articles of Confederation (1781-1789) served as the first constitution of the United States, establishing a "firm league of friendship" among the 13 original states.

While it provided a framework for governance during the American Revolution, its weaknesses led to the Constitutional Convention of 1787 and the creation of the U.S. Constitution.

Explore Timeline Take the Quiz

The first page of the Articles of Confederation

Key Facts at a Glance

Adopted

November 15, 1777

Ratified March 1, 1781

States

13 Original States

Unanimous approval required for amendments

Government

Weak Central Government

No executive or judicial branches

Historical Timeline

Key events during the Articles of Confederation period

1777
Drafting the Articles

The Continental Congress adopts the Articles of Confederation on November 15, 1777, after more than a year of debate.

John Dickinson, primary author of the Articles.

1781
Ratification

Maryland becomes the final state to ratify the Articles on March 1, 1781, making it the first constitution of the United States.

The Maryland State House, where ratification occurred.

1783
Treaty of Paris

The Confederation Congress ratifies the Treaty of Paris on January 14, 1784, officially ending the Revolutionary War.

The first page of the Treaty of Paris.

1786-87
Shays' Rebellion

An armed uprising in Massachusetts, led by Daniel Shays, highlights the weakness of the central government in dealing with internal unrest.

An illustration depicting Shays' Rebellion.

1787
Constitutional Convention

Delegates convene in Philadelphia to revise the Articles but ultimately decide to draft a new Constitution.

Scene at the Signing of the Constitution of the United States.

Historical Documents

Explore key documents from the Confederation Period

The Articles of Confederation

The first constitution of the United States.

The Treaty of Paris

Ended the American Revolutionary War.

Northwest Ordinance

Established a process for admitting new states.

Shays' Rebellion

An uprising that highlighted the weaknesses of the Articles.

Impact and Significance

Why the Articles of Confederation matter today

Strengths & Accomplishments
  • Guided the nation through the end of the Revolutionary War.
  • Negotiated the Treaty of Paris (1783), securing independence.
  • Passed the Northwest Ordinance of 1787.
  • Established foundational departments (Foreign Affairs, War, Marine).
Weaknesses & Failures
  • No power to tax, leading to financial instability.
  • Inability to regulate interstate commerce.
  • Lack of an executive or judicial branch.
  • Unanimous consent required for amendments made it impossible to adapt.
